title: Panicle
text:
A panicle is a much-branched <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>. Some authors distinguish it from a compound spike inflorescence, by requiring that the <a href="flower">flower</a>s (and <a href="fruit">fruit</a>) be <a href="Pedicel%20%28botany%29">pedicellate</a> (having a single stem per flower). The branches of a panicle are often <a href="raceme">raceme</a>s. A panicle may have determinate or indeterminate growth.
This type of inflorescence is largely characteristic of grasses such as <a href="oat">oat</a> and <a href="crabgrass">crabgrass</a>, as well as other plants such as <a href="pistachio">pistachio</a> and <a href="mamoncillo">mamoncillo</a>. Botanists use the term paniculate in two ways: "having a true panicle inflorescence" as well as "having an inflorescence with the form but not necessarily the structure of a panicle".
Corymb.
A <a href="corymb">corymb</a> may have a paniculate branching structure, with the lower flowers having longer <a href="pedicel%20%28botany%29">pedicels</a> than the upper, thus giving a flattish top superficially resembling an <a href="umbel">umbel</a>. Many species in the subfamily <a href="Amygdaloideae">Amygdaloideae</a>, such as <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a>s and <a href="rowan">rowan</a>s, produce their flowers in corymbs.
